Well, I'm not really sure. I guess I just need someone to talk to about stuff that's going on.
User:  Certainly. What would you like to talk about?
Daniel:  I don't know. Just stuff that's going on at home I guess.
User:  Is there something specific that's going on that you're concerned about?
Daniel:  My dad hits my mom.
User:  That must be really tough for you to see.
Daniel:  Yeah. It is. I don't know what to do about it.
User:  Well, it sounds like you're feeling pretty helpless right now.
Daniel:  Yeah. I guess I am.
User:  That's understandable. It's hard to see someone we love being hurt.
Daniel:  Yeah.
User:  Have you talked to anyone else about this? A therapist or counselor maybe?

User:  That's good. It sounds like you're getting some help.
Daniel:  Yeah. I guess so.
User:  Is there anything else you want to talk about today?
Response.1:
Not really sure. Just feeling really down lately.
User: That sounds tough. Can you tell me more about what's going on?
David: Yeah. I guess it all started with my brothers. Both of them are really successful and I felt like I could never measure up. So I started getting angry and lashing out. I took it out on my parents a lot. Yelling, throwing things. It got really bad.
User: That sounds really difficult. I'm glad you're reaching out for help.
David: Yeah. I've been seeing a psychologist and taking medication, but it's just been really hard lately. My parents are really disappointed in me and I just feel like I'm never going to be good enough.
User: I'm sorry to hear that. That must be really tough for you.
David: Yeah. It is. I just don't know what to do.
User: Well, let's talk about some options. What do you think about counseling?
David: I don't know. I'm not really sure if it would help.
User: What about medication?
David: I'm already taking medication. It's just not really helping.
User: Have you tried talking to your brothers?
David: Yeah. We've talked, but they just don't really understand.
User: Well, let's brainstorm some other options. Have you considered therapy?
Response.2:
I'm struggling with my mental health and I was hoping to talk to someone about it.
User: Certainly. How are you doing?
Daniel: Not great. My parents are constantly fighting and it's really taking a toll on me.
User: I'm sorry to hear that. How long has this been going on?
Daniel: It started when I was a kid and it's just been getting worse and worse.
User: That sounds really tough. Have you ever talked to anyone about this before?
Daniel: I've seen a psychologist and I'm on medication, but it's not really helping.
User: It sounds like you've been through a lot. I'm glad you're reaching out for help. I think it would be really beneficial for you to talk to someone who can understand what you're going through.
User: Would you like me to provide some resources?
Response.3:
I don't really know. I guess I just need to talk to someone.
User: Okay, that sounds like a good idea. Do you want to talk about what's been going on?
Daniel: I don't know. It's just, everything is so fucked up.
User: Can you elaborate on that?
Daniel: My brothers and I, we used to be really close. But lately, ever since our parents started fighting, it's like we're all on edge all the time. And I can't stand it. I just feel so angry all the time.
User: It sounds like you're feeling a lot of anger and frustration. That makes sense, considering what you're going through.
Daniel: Yeah. I just, I don't know what to do. It feels like everything is falling apart.
User: That must be really tough for you to deal with. Have you talked to your psychologist about this?
Daniel: Yeah, I have. But it's just, I don't know, it doesn't seem like it's helping.
User: Well, it sounds like you're doing the best you can under the circumstances. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed.
Daniel: Yeah. I just wish things would go back to the way they were.
User: That's understandable. Change can be hard, especially when it's something that's beyond your control.
Daniel: Yeah.
User: Is there anything in particular that you're worried about?
Daniel: I don't know. I guess I'm just worried that things are never going to get better.
User: That's a valid concern. It's natural to feel like that when you're going through something tough.
Daniel: Yeah.
User: Have you considered talking to your brothers about how you're feeling?
Daniel: I don't know. I don't really want to burden them with my problems.
User: That's understandable. But it might be helpful to talk to them about what's going on. They might be able to offer some support.
Daniel: Yeah. I guess that's true.
User: It's also important to remember that you don't have to go through this alone. We're here to support you.
Daniel: Yeah. Thank you.

I don't know. I just feel really bad all the time.
User: That sounds tough. Can you tell me more about why you feel bad?
Daniel: It's just, everything is so hard. My parents are always fighting and my brothers are always picking on me. I just can't take it anymore.
User: I'm so sorry to hear that. That sounds like a really difficult situation to be in. What have you been doing to try and cope with how you're feeling?
Daniel: I've been seeing a psychologist and I'm on some medication, but it's just not helping. I don't know what to do.
User: Well, first of all, it sounds like you're doing everything you can to try and improve your situation. That's really commendable. Have you talked to your family about how you're feeling?

Daniel: No, I haven't. I don't think they'd really understand.
User: I completely understand why you feel that way, but it might be worth a try. Maybe they could be more supportive than you think.
Daniel: I don't know. I just don't see how that could help.
User: Well, it might not help, but it's worth a shot. And if nothing else, it would let them know how you're feeling and that you need their support.
Daniel: Alright, I'll think about it. Thank you for talking to me.
